Clostridium grantii DSM 8605 is an anaerobic, spore-forming, Gram-positive bacterium that was isolated from a soil sample. It is a member of the genus Clostridium, which is known for its ability to produce endospores that can withstand harsh environmental conditions.

This specific strain, DSM 8605, was first isolated and characterized in 1994. It is a rod-shaped bacterium that measures approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 2-6 μm in length. The bacterium is capable of growth at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 40°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 37°C.

Clostridium grantii DSM 8605 is able to ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, as well as some amino acids. The fermentation products produced by this strain include acetate, butyrate, and hydrogen. Additionally, this bacterium is capable of reducing sulfur compounds and can produce spores as a survival mechanism under unfavorable environmental conditions.

The genome of Clostridium grantii DSM 8605 has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential ecological roles. This information can contribute to a better understanding of the diversity and functional roles of clostridia in various environments.
